segment.source: Network security LAN Manager authentication level (Windows 10)
segment.target: Network security LAN Manager authentication level (Windows 10)

segment.source: Describes the best practices, location, values, policy management and security considerations for the Network security LAN Manager authentication level security policy setting.
segment.target: Describes the best practices, location, values, policy management and security considerations for the Network security LAN Manager authentication level security policy setting.

segment.source: Network security: LAN Manager authentication level
segment.target: Network security: LAN Manager authentication level

segment.source: Describes the best practices, location, values, policy management and security considerations for the Network security: LAN Manager authentication level security policy setting.
segment.target: Describes the best practices, location, values, policy management and security considerations for the Network security: LAN Manager authentication level security policy setting.

segment.source: This policy setting determines which challenge or response authentication protocol is used for network logons.
segment.target: This policy setting determines which challenge or response authentication protocol is used for network logons.

segment.source: LAN Manager (LM) includes client computer and server software from Microsoft that allows users to link personal devices together on a single network.
segment.target: LAN Manager (LM) includes client computer and server software from Microsoft that allows users to link personal devices together on a single network.

segment.source: Network capabilities include transparent file and print sharing, user security features, and network administration tools.
segment.target: Network capabilities include transparent file and print sharing, user security features, and network administration tools.

segment.source: In Active Directory domains, the Kerberos protocol is the default authentication protocol.
segment.target: In Active Directory domains, the Kerberos protocol is the default authentication protocol.

segment.source: However, if the Kerberos protocol is not negotiated for some reason, Active Directory uses LM, NTLM, or NTLM version 2 (NTLMv2).
segment.target: However, if the Kerberos protocol is not negotiated for some reason, Active Directory uses LM, NTLM, or NTLM version 2 (NTLMv2).

segment.source: LAN Manager authentication includes the LM, NTLM, and NTLMv2 variants, and it is the protocol that is used to authenticate all client devices running the Windows operating system when they perform the following operations:
segment.target: LAN Manager authentication includes the LM, NTLM, and NTLMv2 variants, and it is the protocol that is used to authenticate all client devices running the Windows operating system when they perform the following operations:

segment.source: Authenticate to domains based on earlier versions of the Windows operating system
segment.target: Authenticate to domains based on earlier versions of the Windows operating system

segment.source: Authenticate to computers that do not run Windows operating systems, beginning with Windows 2000
segment.target: Authenticate to computers that do not run Windows operating systems, beginning with Windows 2000

segment.source: Authenticate to computers that are not in the domain
segment.target: Authenticate to computers that are not in the domain

segment.source: Send LM & NTLM - use NTLMv2 session security if negotiated
segment.target: Send LM & NTLM - use NTLMv2 session security if negotiated

segment.source: The Network security: LAN Manager authentication level setting determines which challenge/response authentication protocol is used for network logons.
segment.target: The Network security: LAN Manager authentication level setting determines which challenge/response authentication protocol is used for network logons.

segment.source: This choice affects the authentication protocol level that clients use, the session security level that the computers negotiate, and the authentication level that servers accept.
segment.target: This choice affects the authentication protocol level that clients use, the session security level that the computers negotiate, and the authentication level that servers accept.

segment.source: The following table identifies the policy settings, describes the setting, and identifies the security level used in the corresponding registry setting if you choose to use the registry to control this setting instead of the policy setting.
segment.target: The following table identifies the policy settings, describes the setting, and identifies the security level used in the corresponding registry setting if you choose to use the registry to control this setting instead of the policy setting.

segment.source: Client devices use LM and NTLM authentication, and they never use NTLMv2 session security.
segment.target: Client devices use LM and NTLM authentication, and they never use NTLMv2 session security.

segment.source: Domain controllers accept LM, NTLM, and NTLMv2 authentication.
segment.target: Domain controllers accept LM, NTLM, and NTLMv2 authentication.

segment.source: Send LM NTLM – use NTLMv2 session security if negotiated
segment.target: Send LM NTLM – use NTLMv2 session security if negotiated

segment.source: Client devices use LM and NTLM authentication, and they use NTLMv2 session security if the server supports it.
segment.target: Client devices use LM and NTLM authentication, and they use NTLMv2 session security if the server supports it.

segment.source: Domain controllers accept LM, NTLM, and NTLMv2 authentication.
segment.target: Domain controllers accept LM, NTLM, and NTLMv2 authentication.

segment.source: Client devices use NTLMv1 authentication, and they use NTLMv2 session security if the server supports it.
segment.target: Client devices use NTLMv1 authentication, and they use NTLMv2 session security if the server supports it.

segment.source: Domain controllers accept LM, NTLM, and NTLMv2 authentication.
segment.target: Domain controllers accept LM, NTLM, and NTLMv2 authentication.

segment.source: Client devices use NTLMv2 authentication, and they use NTLMv2 session security if the server supports it.
segment.target: Client devices use NTLMv2 authentication, and they use NTLMv2 session security if the server supports it.

segment.source: Domain controllers accept LM, NTLM, and NTLMv2 authentication.
segment.target: Domain controllers accept LM, NTLM, and NTLMv2 authentication.

segment.source: Client devices use NTLMv2 authentication, and they use NTLMv2 session security if the server supports it.
segment.target: Client devices use NTLMv2 authentication, and they use NTLMv2 session security if the server supports it.

segment.source: Domain controllers refuse to accept LM authentication, and they will accept only NTLM and NTLMv2 authentication.
segment.target: Domain controllers refuse to accept LM authentication, and they will accept only NTLM and NTLMv2 authentication.

segment.source: Client devices use NTLMv2 authentication, and they use NTLMv2 session security if the server supports it.
segment.target: Client devices use NTLMv2 authentication, and they use NTLMv2 session security if the server supports it.

segment.source: Domain controllers refuse to accept LM and NTLM authentication, and they will accept only NTLMv2 authentication.
segment.target: Domain controllers refuse to accept LM and NTLM authentication, and they will accept only NTLMv2 authentication.

segment.source: Best practices are dependent on your specific security and authentication requirements.
segment.target: Best practices are dependent on your specific security and authentication requirements.

segment.source: Computer ConfigurationWindows SettingsSecurity SettingsLocal PoliciesSecurity Options
segment.target: Computer ConfigurationWindows SettingsSecurity SettingsLocal PoliciesSecurity Options

segment.source: The following table lists the actual and effective default values for this policy.
segment.target: The following table lists the actual and effective default values for this policy.

segment.source: Default values are also listed on the policy’s property page.
segment.target: Default values are also listed on the policy’s property page.

segment.source: This section describes features and tools that are available to help you manage this policy.
segment.target: This section describes features and tools that are available to help you manage this policy.

segment.source: Changes to this policy become effective without a device restart when they are saved locally or distributed through Group Policy.
segment.target: Changes to this policy become effective without a device restart when they are saved locally or distributed through Group Policy.

segment.source: Modifying this setting may affect compatibility with client devices, services, and applications.
segment.target: Modifying this setting may affect compatibility with client devices, services, and applications.

segment.source: This section describes how an attacker might exploit a feature or its configuration, how to implement the countermeasure, and the possible negative consequences of countermeasure implementation.
segment.target: This section describes how an attacker might exploit a feature or its configuration, how to implement the countermeasure, and the possible negative consequences of countermeasure implementation.

segment.source: In Windows 7 and Windows Vista, this setting is undefined.
segment.target: In Windows 7 and Windows Vista, this setting is undefined.

segment.source: In Windows Server 2008 R2 and later, this setting is configured to Send NTLMv2 responses only.
segment.target: In Windows Server 2008 R2 and later, this setting is configured to Send NTLMv2 responses only.

segment.source: Configure the Network security: LAN Manager Authentication Level setting to Send NTLMv2 responses only.
segment.target: Configure the Network security: LAN Manager Authentication Level setting to Send NTLMv2 responses only.

segment.source: Microsoft and a number of independent organizations strongly recommend this level of authentication when all client computers support NTLMv2.
segment.target: Microsoft and a number of independent organizations strongly recommend this level of authentication when all client computers support NTLMv2.

segment.source: Client devices that do not support NTLMv2 authentication cannot authenticate in the domain and access domain resources by using LM and NTLM.
segment.target: Client devices that do not support NTLMv2 authentication cannot authenticate in the domain and access domain resources by using LM and NTLM.
